CIVIL EMERGENCIES
§ 33.001 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   CIVIL EMERGENCY.
      (1)   A “riot or unlawful assembly” characterized by the use of actual
force or violence or any power to execute by three or more persons acting
together without authority of law; or
      (2)   Any “natural disaster” or “man-made calamity,” including flood,
conflagration, cyclone, tornado, earthquake or explosion within the corporate
limits of the village resulting in the death or injury of persons or the
destruction of property to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be
taken to protect the public health, safety and welfare.
   CURFEW. A prohibition against any person or persons walking, running,
loitering, standing or motoring upon any alley, street, highway, public
property or vacant premises within the corporate limits of the village,
excepting officials of any governmental unit and persons officially designated
to duty with reference to the civil emergency.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-1)
§ 33.002 DECLARATION OF EMERGENCY.
   Whenever an emergency, as defined in §
33.001, exists, the Mayor shall declare the existence by means of a written
declaration, setting forth the facts which constitute the emergency.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-2)
§ 33.003 CURFEW.
   After proclamation of a civil emergency by the Mayor, he or she may order a
general curfew applicable to the geographical areas of the village or to the
village as a whole as he or she deems advisable and applicable during such
hours of the day or night as he or she deems necessary in the interest of the
public safety and welfare.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-3)
§ 33.004 AUTHORITY OF MAYOR TO ISSUE ORDERS.
   After the proclamation of a civil emergency, the Mayor may also, in the
interest of public safety and welfare, make any or all of the following orders:
   (A)   Order the closing of all retail liquor stores, including taverns and
private clubs or portions thereof wherein the consumption of intoxicating
liquor and beer is permitted;
   (B)   Order the discontinuance of the sale of alcoholic liquor by any
wholesaler or retailer;
   (C)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away of
gasoline or other flammable liquid or combustible products in any container
other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle;
   (D)   Order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or
giving away of any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever; and
   (E)   Issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection
of life and property.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-4)
§ 33.005 EFFECTIVENESS.
   The proclamation herein authorized shall be effective for a period of 48
hours unless sooner terminated by a proclamation of the Mayor indicating that
the civil emergency no longer exists. The Mayor shall have the power to re-
proclaim the existence of a civil emergency at the end of each 48-hour period
during the time the civil emergency exists.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-5)
§ 33.006 NOTIFICATION.
   Upon issuing the proclamation herein authorized, the Mayor shall notify the
news media situated within the village and shall cause three copies of the
proclamation declaring the existence of the emergency to be posted at the
following places within the village:
   (A)   The Village Hall;
   (B)   The Post Office; and
   (C)   The County Courthouse.
(`92 Code, § 30-1-6)
POLICE DEPARTMENT
§ 33.020 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established a department of the municipal government of the
village which shall be known as the Police Department. The Police Department
shall consist of the Mayor, as Police Commissioner, the Chief of Police and of
the number of patrol persons as may be provided from time to time by the
Village Board.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-1)
Cross-reference:
   Public Service Officer established, see §§
33.160 et seq.
§ 33.021 OFFICE OF CHIEF CREATED; DUTIES.
   (A)   There is hereby established the office of the Chief of Police. The
Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of
the Village Board.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-2)
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall keep records and make reports concerning the
activities of his or her Department as may be required. The Chief shall be
responsible for the performance of the Police Department, of all its functions
and all persons who are members of the Department shall serve subject to the
orders of the Chief of Police.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-3)
§ 33.021.1 OFFICE OF DEPUTY CHIEF CREATED; DUTIES.
   (A)   There is hereby established the office of the Deputy Chief of Police.
The Deputy Chief of Police shall be appointed by the Chief of Police. The rank
of Deputy Chief of Police shall be an exempt rank immediately below that of the
Chief of Police. The Deputy Chief of Police shall be appointed from any rank of
sworn, full-time officers of the Village Police Department, provided such
officer has at least five years of full-time service as a police officer for
the village. The Deputy Chief of Police shall serve at the discretion of the
Chief of Police and, if removed from such office, shall revert to the rank
currently held, without regard as to whether a vacancy exists in that rank.
   (B)   The Deputy Chief of Police shall provide those services as required by
the Chief of Police. In the event there is a vacancy in the office of Chief of
Police, or in the event the Chief of Police is incapacitated or otherwise not
able to perform the duties of the office, the Deputy Chief of Police shall have
the same powers and duties generally as that of the Chief of Police, during any
vacancy in that office or during the absence or incapacity of the Chief of
Police. The Deputy Chief of Police shall possess such powers and duties until
such time as the vacancy in the office of Chief of Police is filled, or until
such time as the Chief of Police is no longer absent or incapacitated.
   (C)   The compensation for the office of Deputy Chief of Police shall be
established from time to time by the Village President and Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2011-02, passed 1-19-11)
§ 33.022 APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   A sufficient number of patrol persons shall be appointed by the Mayor,
by and with the advice and consent of the Village Board, to serve for one year
or until his or her successor is appointed and qualified.
   (B)   A police officer may be appointed to office by the Mayor and Village
Board if he or she meets the necessary qualifications, notwithstanding the fact
that the police officer is not a resident of the village when appointed or when
he or she is to serve as such an official.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-4)
§ 33.023 SALARY; COMPENSATION.
   (A)   The Police Department shall receive compensation as may be provided by
village ordinance or by resolution of the Village Board.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-5)
   (B)   Auxiliary police officers shall receive hourly compensation for their
services as determined by the corporate authorities, provided the services are
performed at the direction of the Chief of Police.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-19)
§ 33.024 DUTIES.
   (A)   The police officers shall devote his or her entire time to the
performance of the duties of his or her office and is hereby charged with the
preservation of the peace, order and safety of the village and with the duty of
protecting the rights of persons and property and of enforcing all laws and
also all orders of the Village Board.
   (B)   (1)   He or she shall take notice of all nuisances, obstructions and
defects on the highways or other public places and shall cause the same to be
abated or removed or immediate notice thereof given to the proper officer,
whose duty it may be to take action in relation thereto.
      (2)   When requested by the Mayor, he or she shall attend, either in
person or by deputy, all meetings of the Village Board, execute all its orders
and close the Board Chamber upon the adjournment of that body.
   (C)   He or she shall also execute all warrants or other legal process
required to be executed by him or her under any ordinance of the village or
laws of the state.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-6)
§ 33.025 MUTUAL AID CONTRACT.
   The Police Department, with the approval of the Village Board, may enter
into an agreement to provide police protection to neighboring municipalities.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-7)
§ 33.026 SPECIAL POLICE OFFICERS.
   The Mayor may, on special occasions when, in his or her judgment for public
peace and order of the village shall require, appoint and commission any number
of special police officers as may be necessary and shall fix in order of their
appointment, the time during which each shall serve and all such special police
officers, during such time, shall possess the powers and exercise the duties of
regular police patrol persons; provided that their appointment, if for more
than ten days shall be subject to the consent of the Village Board in the
manner that other appointments to office by the Mayor are subject. Auxiliary
police officers shall not carry firearms, except with the permission of the
Mayor and then only when in uniform and in the performance of their duties.
They shall have a current and valid certification for the duties they are
required to perform.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-9)
§ 33.027 LEGAL PROCESSES.
   All police shall have the power and authority to execute village warrants or
other similar legal processes outside the corporate limits of the village and
within such distance therefrom as authorized by law in all cases when any
ordinance of the Village Board made pursuant to law shall prescribe a penalty
for the violation of any of its provisions by persons residing, acting or doing
any business within the limits of the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-10)
§ 33.028 ASSISTING POLICE OFFICERS AND FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   Every police officer of the village may, at any time, call upon any
able-bodied person(s) above the age of 18 years to aid him or her in the
arresting, retaking or holding in custody of any person guilty of having
committed any unlawful act or charged therewith, or to aid the officer in
preventing the commission of any unlawful act.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-11)
   (B)   Every police officer shall aid the Fire Department by giving the alarm
in case of fire and in clearing the streets or grounds in the immediate
vicinity of any fire so that the firefighters shall not be hindered or
obstructed in the performance of their duties.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-12)
§ 33.029 FAILURE TO PERFORM.
   Any member of the Police Department who shall neglect or refuse to perform
any duty required of him or her by this code or the rules and regulations of
the Department, or who shall be, in the discharge of his or her official
duties, guilty of any fraud, favoritism, extortion, oppressions or willful
wrong or injustice, shall be subject to removal from office.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-13)
§ 33.030 AIDING IN ESCAPE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to resist or obstruct any
member of the Police Force in the discharge of his or her duty or to endeavor
to do so, in any manner, assist any person in the custody of any member of the
Police Department to escape or to attempt to escape from custody or to attempt
to rescue any person in custody.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-14)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 33.031 USE OF INTOXICATING LIQUOR.
   No member on an active tour of duty or while wearing the official police
officer’s badge of the village shall indulge in the use of intoxicating liquor
of any kind. Intoxication, at any time, shall be sufficient cause for removal.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-15)
§ 33.032 WITNESS FEES.
   Any member of the Police Department shall appear as witness whenever this is
necessary in a prosecution for a violation of an ordinance or of any state or
federal law. No member shall retain any witness fee for service as witness in
any action or suit to which the village is a party, except those fees paid by
the village. Fees paid for the services shall be turned over to the Chief of
Police who shall deposit the same with the Village Treasurer.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-16)
§ 33.033 RULES AND REGULATIONS GENERALLY.
   The Chief of Police may make or prescribe such rules and regulations for the
conduct and guidance of the members of the Police Department as he or she shall
deem advisable and such rules, when approved by the Mayor, shall be binding on
such members.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-17)
§ 33.034 TRAINING.
   Auxiliary police officers, prior to entering upon any of their duties, shall
receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police procedures
by the proper authorities. The courses of training shall not be less than 40
hours in duration. Upon completion of the course of training, the applicant
shall file with a certificate attesting to the completion of the course with
the Mayor or Chief of Police.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-18)
§ 33.035 STOLEN PROPERTY.
   The Chief of Police shall be the custodian of all lost and abandoned or
stolen property in the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-20)
Statutory reference:
   Stolen property provisions, see ILCS Chapter 765, Act 1030, §§ 0.01 et seq.
§ 33.036 POLICE DEPARTMENT FEES FOR ADMINISTRATIVE TASKS.
   (A)   The village Police Department shall charge administrative fees for the
performance of various Police Department related tasks and the fees shall be
set as follows:
      (1)   Police report: $5;
      (2)   Records check: $10;
      (3)   Fingerprints: $10;
      (4)   Tow release: $150;
      (5)   Sex offender registration (initial): $20;
      (6)   Sex offender registration (renewal): $10; and
      (7)   Bail processing fee; $20.
   (B)   The above mentioned fees may be reviewed periodically by the village
corporate authorities and some of all of the said fees may be amended form time
to time.
   (C)   The administrative fees as listed in division (A) shall be paid to the
Police Department by cash only except for police report fees (which may be paid
by cash or check), and shall be deposited into the village general fund and
shall be earmarked for the purchase of Police Department equipment and/or
vehicles.
(Ord. 2017-28, passed 9-6-17; Am. Ord. 2024-45, passed 6-19-24)
FALSE ALARMS
§ 33.045 FEE FOR FALSE ALARMS.
   Any person, persons, business or corporation owning or operating alarm
equipment in the village and whose equipment generates three or more false
alarms to the village or any of its personnel within any one 12-month period
from May 1 to April 30 shall be liable to reimburse the village according to
the following schedule:
   (A)   For each false alarm over two, reimbursement to the village shall be
at the rate of not less than $25, nor more than $500.
   (B)   For each false alarm over five, reimbursement to the village shall be
at the rate of not less than $50, nor more than $500.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-21) (Ord. 96-02, passed 3-2-96)
§ 33.046 FAILURE TO PAY ASSESSMENT.
   In the event that any fee is not paid within 15 days after billing, the
village may institute a civil action to collect the same and may forthwith
disconnect any such equipment from any village building or facility and
promptly terminate monitoring thereof.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-22) (Ord. 96-02, passed 3-2-96)
§ 33.047 MALFUNCTION EXCEPTION.
   (A)   If a false alarm was caused by a verifiable malfunction in telephone
lines or equipment not located at the premises at which the alarm is installed,
the person, persons, business or corporation shall not be liable for that
malfunction.
   (B)   The person, persons, business or corporation shall provide proof that
the malfunction was not their fault upon request.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-23) (Ord. 96-02, passed 3-2-96)
§ 33.048 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   FALSE ALARM. Any and all engaging of burglar alarms (when there has been no
breach of the peace, no burglary, theft or intruder), fire alarms (when there
is no fire or smoke present), panic or hold up alarms (when there is no
trouble, intruder or thief present), or if the engagement of the alarm was
caused by human error or equipment malfunction at the premises on which the
alarm is installed.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-24) (Ord. 96-02, passed 3-2-96)
§ 33.049 LIABILITY OF PARTY FOR INJURIES.
   Any person, persons, business or corporation found responsible for any false
alarm in excess of two in one 12-month period shall be liable to the village
for all direct damages and injuries resulting therefrom.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-25) (Ord. 96-02, passed 3-2-96)
AUXILIARY POLICE
§ 33.060 APPOINTMENT.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to appoint auxiliary police officers as
employees, subject to the advice and consent of the Village Board. Prior to
appointment, all proposed auxiliary police officers shall be fingerprinted and
their fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Identification,
Washington, D.C. for any possible criminal record. No person shall be appointed
as an auxiliary police officer if he or she has been convicted of a felony or
other crime involving moral turpitude. All appointees shall be at least 18
years of age. The appointment of any or all auxiliary police officers may be
terminated by the Mayor, subject to the advice and consent of the Village
Board.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-30)
§ 33.061 SEPARATE FROM POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   Auxiliary police officers shall not be members of the regular Police
Department and shall be residents of the village. Identification symbols worn
by the auxiliary police officers shall be different and distinct from those
used by the regular Police Department and shall be selected and chosen by the
Chief of Police. Auxiliary police officers shall, at all times during the
performance of their duties, be subject to the direction and control of the
Chief of Police.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-31)
§ 33.062 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Auxiliary police officers shall have the following powers and duties, when
properly assigned and on duty:
   (A)   To aid or direct traffic in the municipality;
   (B)   To aid in control of natural or man-made disasters;
   (C)   To aid in case of civil disorder;
   (D)   To perform normal and regular police duties when assigned by the Chief
of Police on occasions when it is impractical for members of the regular Police
Department to perform normal and regular duties;
   (E)   To arrest or cause to be arrested, with or without process, all
persons who break the peace or are found violating any municipal ordinance or
any criminal law of the state;
   (F)   To commit arrested persons for examination;
   (G)   If necessary, to detain arrested persons in custody overnight or
Sunday in any safe place or until they can be brought before the proper
magistrate;
   (H)   To exercise all other powers as conservators of the peace that the
corporate authorities may prescribe; and
   (I)   To serve and execute all warrants for the violation of municipal
ordinances or the state criminal law, within the corporate limits of the
village, and also on any property owned and controlled by the village beyond
its corporate limits and for this purpose, to have all the common law and
statutory power of sheriffs.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-32)
§ 33.063 FIREARMS PROHIBITED.
   Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms, except with the
permission of the Chief of Police and then only when in uniform and in the
performance of their duties.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-33)
§ 33.064 TRAINING.
   (A)   Prior to entering upon any of their duties, auxiliary police officers
shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other police
procedure by the Chief of Police or through a course of training designated by
him or her.
   (B)   The course of training shall be not less than 40 hours in duration.
   (C)   Upon completion of the course of training, the Chief of Police shall
file a certificate attesting to the auxiliary police officer’s completion of
the course with the Village Clerk.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-34)
§ 33.065 COMPENSATION.
   Auxiliary police officers may receive compensation as provided by the
Village Board.
(`92 Code, § 30-2-35)
EMERGENCY SERVICES AND DISASTER AGENCY
§ 33.075 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   There is hereby created the Village Emergency Services and Disaster
Agency to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or damage resulting
from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other hostile action or from
natural or man-made disaster, in accordance with “The Illinois Emergency
Services and Disaster Act of 1988” (ILCS Chapter 20, Act 3305, §§ 1 et seq.)
and any amendments thereto.
   (B)   This ESDA shall consist of the Coordinator and such additional members
as may be selected by the Coordinator.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-1)
§ 33.076 COORDINATOR.
   (A)   The Coordinator of the Village ESDA shall be appointed by the Mayor,
with the advice and consent of the Village Board, and shall serve until removed
by same.
   (B)   The Coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training and operation of the ESDA, subject to the direction
and control of the Mayor, as provided by statute.
   (C)   In the event of the absence, resignation, death or inability to serve
as the Coordinator, the Mayor or any person designated by him or her shall be
and act as Coordinator until a new appointment is made as provided in this
code.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-2)
§ 33.077 FUNCTIONS.
   The ESDA shall perform such ESDA functions within the village as shall be
prescribed in and by the State ESDA plan and program prepared by the Governor,
and such orders, rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Governor
and, in addition, shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may
be required pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political
subdivision, municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided in the
“State ESDA Act of 1988” and any amendments thereto.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-3)
§ 33.078 SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM.
   (A)   All or any members of the ESDA organization may be designated as
members of a mobile support team created by the Director of the State ESDA, as
provided by law.
   (B)   The leader of the mobile support team shall be designated by the
Coordinator of the ESDA organization.
   (C)   (1)   Any member of a mobile support team who is a village employee or
officer while serving on call to duty by the Governor or the State Director
shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and
immunities incident to the employment or office.
      (2)   Any member who is not a paid officer or employee of the village,
while so serving, shall receive from the state, reasonable compensation as
provided by law.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-4)
§ 33.079 AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS.
   The Coordinator of ESDA may negotiate mutual aid agreements with other
cities or political subdivisions of the state, but no such agreement shall be
effective until it has been approved by the Mayor.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-5)
§ 33.080 EMERGENCY ACTION.
   If the Governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists in the event of
actual enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state
of a major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or
from man-made or natural disaster, it shall be the duty of the ESDA to
cooperate fully with the State ESDA and with the governor in the exercise of
emergency powers as provided by law.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-6)
§ 33.081 COMPENSATION.
   (A)   Members of the ESDA who are paid village employees or officers, if
called for training by the State Director of ESDA, shall receive, for the time
spent in the training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the position
held.
   (B)   Members who are not village employees or officers shall receive, for
the training, compensation as may be established by the Mayor.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-7)
§ 33.082 REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE.
   The Village Treasurer may receive and allocate, to the appropriate fund, any
reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the ESDA, as prescribed by the State Director of ESDA, compensation
for services and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving
outside the village in response to a call by the Governor or State Director of
ESDA, as provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state
incident to ESDA activities as provided by law.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-8)
§ 33.083 PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES.
   (A)   The Mayor may, upon recommendation of the Village Coordinator of ESDA,
authorize any purchase of contracts necessary to place the village in a
position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of any
nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and safety,
protect property and provide emergency assistance to victims in the case of
disaster or from man-made or natural disaster.
   (B)   In the event of enemy caused or other disaster, the Village
Coordinator of ESDA is authorized, on behalf of the village, to procure the
services, supplies, equipment or materials as may be necessary for such
purposes, in view of the exigency without regard to the statutory procedures or
formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to village contracts or
obligations, as authorized by “The State ESDA Act of 1988”, and amendments
thereto, provided that if the Mayor meets at such time, he or she shall act
subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by that body.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-9)
§ 33.084 OATH.
   Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Village ESDA
organization shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to the
following oath, which shall be filed with the Coordinator:
“I,                                       , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that
I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the
Constitution of the United States of America, and the Constitution of the State
of Illinois and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public
and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this
obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and
that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to
enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor
have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the ESDA
organization, I will not advocate, nor become a member of any political party
or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence.”
(`92 Code, § 30-3-10)
§ 33.085 OFFICE SPACE.
   The Mayor is authorized to designate space in a village building or
elsewhere as may be provided for by the Mayor for the Village ESDA as its
office.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-11)
§ 33.086 LOCAL DISASTER EMERGENCIES.
   (A)   (1)   A local disaster emergency may be declared only by the principal
executive officer of a political subdivision.
      (2)   It shall not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of
seven days, except by or with the consent of the governing board of the
political subdivision.
      (3)   Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing or terminating a
local disaster emergency shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall
be filed promptly with the County Clerk or the Municipal Clerk, as the case may
be, in the area to which it applies.
   (B)   The effect of a declaration of a local disaster emergency is to
activate the response and recovery aspects of any and all applicable local or
inter-jurisdictional disaster emergency plans and to authorize the furnishing
of aid and assistance thereunder.
   (C)   No inter-jurisdictional agency or official thereof may declare a local
disaster emergency unless expressly authorized by the agreement pursuant to
which the agency functions.
   (D)   However, an inter-jurisdictional disaster agency shall provide aid and
services in accordance with the agreement pursuant to which it functions.
(`92 Code, § 30-3-12)
FIRE DEPARTMENT
§ 33.100 DEPARTMENT ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Fire Department for the prevention and
extinguishment of fire endangering life and property within the limits of the
village and beyond the village limits where contractual fire protection
agreements have been or may be made by or with the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-1)
   (B)   (1)   The personnel of the Fire Department, who shall be called
“firefighter” or “firefighters,” shall consist of part-time employees who shall
be hired by the Village Mayor and Board of Trustees in the same manner as other
village employees. All such employees shall be of the minimum age of 18 years
and shall consist in number as may, from time to time, be found necessary to
carry out the functions of the Fire Department, such as the prevention and
extinguishing of fires and responding to emergencies. Village officials and
employees of other departments shall be eligible as personnel of the Fire
Department, but shall be compensated for services rendered as a firefighter
while on duty as an employee of the village in some other capacity.
Additionally, all village officers and department heads, whether elected or
appointed, shall be included for receiving compensation for services as a
firefighter.
      (2)   All part-time and volunteer personnel of the Fire Department shall
reside within four miles of the village fire station to either be appointed as
a member or to retain their membership.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-2) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86; Am. Ord. 93-15, passed 5-19-
93; Am. Ord. 2010-07, passed 3-17-10; Am. Ord. 2012-08, passed 4-18-12)
§ 33.101 COMPENSATION AND BENEFITS.
   (A)   Firefighters, including officers of the Department, shall receive such
compensation as shall be determined by the Village Board from time to time or
in the village’s annual appropriation ordinance.
   (B)   Compensation shall also include any payments paid by the Fire
Department or the village towards any death benefit and/or retirement fund. The
village shall pay on behalf of its firefighters all assessments and moneys
required to secure the pension and death benefits available through the County
Firemen’s Association.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-3) (Ord. 83-3, passed 5-4-83; Am. Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.102 PHYSICAL FITNESS.
   (A)   All persons employed as a firefighter shall be physically capable of
carrying out the duties of a firefighter and shall submit to a physical
examination to determine their physical fitness upon the orders of the Village
Mayor, Village Board or the Fire Chief. The physical examination shall be at
the expense of the village and shall be made by a doctor selected by the
authority directing the examination.
   (B)   Any firefighter directed to undergo a physical fitness examination
shall be temporarily suspended from active duty as a firefighter until the
examination is had and a favorable result had from the examination, the
examination to be held within 15 days of the suspension.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-4) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.103 OFFICERS.
   (A)   From the personnel of the Fire Department, there shall be appointed a
Fire Chief, who shall be the head of and in full charge of the Fire Department,
an Assistant Fire Chief, a Deputy Fire Chief, up to four Captains and up to
four Lieutenants.
   (B)   The appointment of the Fire Chief and Assistant Fire Chief shall be
made annually, at the first Village Board meeting in May by the Mayor with the
advice and consent of the Village Board. The appointment of the Deputy Chief,
Captain(s) and Lieutenant(s) shall be made by the Fire Chief as needed.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-5) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86; Am. Ord. 2015-12, passed 4-
15-15)
§ 33.104 FIRE CHIEF; DUTIES.
   (A)   The Fire Chief shall, at all times, have full control and command over
all employees of the Department, the fire apparatus and equipment belonging to
the village and their usage in accomplishing the objectives of the Department.
   (B)   In addition, he or she shall be responsible for the following
activity, doing it either himself or herself or delegating it to subordinates:
      (1)   Formulate and establish a set of administrative rules and
regulations to govern the Department’s fire prevention, fire protection and
firefighting operations, which rules and regulations shall be approved by the
Village Board before they shall become effective;
      (2)   Determine the response of fire apparatus and manpower to alarms and
shall, himself or herself, attend fires;
      (3)   Conduct suitable drills and/or instructions at least monthly for
the members of the Department, in the operation and handling of fire equipment,
first aid, salvage, study of buildings within the village and in the industrial
area, fire prevention, water supplies and all other matters essential to good
firemanship and the safety of life and property from fire; (He or she may
delegate the instruction to others especially qualified in particular
subjects.)
      (4)   Keep, or cause to be kept, at Fire Department headquarters,
complete records of all fires, inspections, investigations, apparatus and
equipment, hose records, purchase and maintenance cost of equipment, personnel,
attendance at meetings and at fires and all other pertinent information about
the Department and its operation;
      (5)   Report, at least quarterly, to the Village Mayor and Board on the
condition of the village’s fire apparatus and equipment, together with
recommendations for any changes or repairs necessary to keep it fully
operative; (He or she may consult with and recommend to the appropriate
Committee of the Board regarding any matter affecting the equipment or
personnel of the Department.)
      (6)   Render a complete annual report in writing to the Village Mayor and
Board by the second Board meeting in May of each year, the report to include
summaries of the information required in the preceding divisions herein,
together with his or her recommendations for improving the effectiveness of the
Department;
      (7)   Consult with village officials and the Fire Committee, at all
times, so that the rules and regulations he or she may prescribe for the
government of the Department are not at variance with state law and the village
code; and
      (8)   Assist proper authority in suppressing the crime of arson by
investigating, or causing to be investigated, the cause origin, and
circumstances of all fires within the Department’s jurisdiction. He or she
shall immediately report all suspicious fires to the Chief of Police for
appropriate police actions.
   (C)   He or she shall have the authority to enter, at reasonable hours of
the day, and upon reasonable notice of the intent to inspect, or cause to be
entered by designated subordinates, any and all buildings and premises for the
purpose of making inspections or investigating fires and their causes, and
shall serve written notice on the building owners or occupants of property to
abate, within a specified reasonable time, any and all fire hazards found and
ordered abated.
   (D)   In the inspection of structures and the investigations of fires, he or
she shall enforce, or cause to be enforced, all laws of the state and village
covering the following:
      (1)   The prevention of fires;
      (2)   The storage and use of explosives and flammables;
      (3)   The installation and maintenance of automatic and other fire alarm
systems and fire extinguishing equipment;
      (4)   The means and adequacy of exit in case of fire from factories,
schools, motels, lodging houses, asylums, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters,
amphitheaters and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or
congregate, from time to time for any purpose;
      (5)   The maintenance and regulation of fire escapes; and
      (6)   Such other preventative and protective fire measures as sound fire
engineering practices of the time advocate.
   (E)   Before licenses are issued by the village for keeping, storing, using,
manufacturing, selling, handling, transporting or other disposition of highly
flammable and/or hazardous materials, rubbish, petroleum products, powder,
explosives, fireworks and similar flammables, he or she shall inspect and
approve the receptacles, vehicles, buildings or storage places and premises to
be used for any such purpose.
   (F)   (1)   The Fire Chief shall inspect, or cause to be inspected, at least
semiannually, all mercantile property within the village, all industrial
property, churches, schools and places of public assemblage, so as to eliminate
fire hazards therein.
      (2)   He or she shall also check the locations where permits for
flammables and/or hazardous materials and the like mentioned herein were issued
to maintain the safe usage, handling or storage.
   (G)   The Chief shall have the power to modify the provisions of any fire-
safety law when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the
strict letter of the law, provided, the spirit of the law is observed and the
modification is clearly stated in writing.
   (H)   The Chief shall execute such other duties and responsibilities as the
Mayor and Board may direct.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-6) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.104.1 OFFICE OF DEPUTY FIRE CHIEF CREATED; DUTIES.
   (A)   There is hereby established the office of the Deputy Fire Chief. The
Deputy Fire Chief shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent
of the Village Board. The rank of Deputy Fire Chief shall be an exempt rank
immediately below that of the Fire Chief. The Deputy Fire Chief shall possess
and maintain certifications of a firefighter/paramedic. The Deputy Fire Chief
shall serve at the discretion of the Fire Chief and Mayor and, if removed from
the office, shall revert to the rank previously held, without regard as to
whether a vacancy exists in that rank.
   (B)   The Deputy Fire Chief shall be second in command to the Fire Chief.
The Deputy Fire Chief shall be responsible to and report to the Fire Chief,
pursuant to the statutes of the state, ordinances of the village, and the
resolutions, motions and directives of the corporate authorities. The Deputy
Fire Chief shall provide those services as required by the Fire Chief. In the
event there is a vacancy in the office of Fire Chief, or in the event the Fire
Chief is incapacitated or otherwise not able to perform the duties of the
office, the Deputy Fire Chief shall have the same powers and duties generally
as that of the Fire Chief during any vacancy in that office or during the
absence or incapacity of the Fire Chief. The Deputy Fire Chief shall possess
such powers and duties until such time as the vacancy in the office of Fire
Chief is filled or until such time as the Fire Chief is no longer absent or
incapacitated.
   (C)   The compensation for the office of Deputy Fire Chief shall be
established from time to time by the Mayor and Village Board of Trustees.
(Ord. 2018-20, passed 5-2-18)
§ 33.105 APPARATUS AND EQUIPMENT.
   (A)   The Village Board shall determine with the advice and counsel of the
Fire Chief, the amount, type and size of all fire apparatus and equipment
comprising the Fire Department, and shall purchase, repair or replace any and
all fire apparatus and equipment and accessories they deem necessary as
provided by state law.
   (B)   In addition:
      (1)   The Village Board shall designate and provide safe and convenient
housing for all fire apparatus and equipment.
      (2)   The Village Board shall establish suitable arrangements for
notifying all personnel of the Department of alarms of fire or emergency and it
is incumbent upon all firefighters to arrange for forwarding alarms to
themselves when they are called away from home or their place of business.
      (3)   No person shall use any fire apparatus or equipment of the village
for any private purpose; nor shall any person willfully and without proper
authority take away or conceal any article used in any way by the Fire
Department.
      (4)   Calls for fire-aid from neighboring communities necessitating any
response of any apparatus or manpower of the Department shall have the consent
of the Mayor, or the Fire Chief or, in case neither can be contacted, the next
subordinate officer of the Department, before response may be made beyond the
Department’s jurisdiction, unless the calls for aid are made pursuant to mutual
aid agreements entered into by the Village Board.
      (5)   The Mayor is hereby authorized, with the approval of the Village
Board, to enter into agreements with contiguous fire protection districts,
properly formed under state law and adjacent municipalities; provided, the
agreements shall specify that the officer-in-charge of the Fire Department
shall have the authority to refuse response to the calls, if, in his or her
judgment, the absence of fire apparatus would unduly endanger the protection of
the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-7) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.106 DUTIES OF PERSONNEL.
   (A)   It shall be the function and duty of the Fire Department and every
firefighter to:
      (1)   Upon the alarm of fire or emergency, to report for duty as soon as
possible; and
      (2)   It is the duty of each active member to attend Departmental
training, meetings and special events.
   (B)   Minimum requirement standards for active membership and to remain in
good standing shall be as follows:
      (1)   Attendance of a minimum of 15 hours per quarter and/or 60 hours
annual training which can be met by attendance of department training or other
outside training approved by the Fire Chief or his/her designee.
      (2)   Reporting for duty to 15% of all non-EMS calls for service answered
by the Department;
      (3)   Attendance of six regular fire department meetings annually which
can be met by attendance and/or absence excused by the Fire Chief or his or her
designee for good cause.
   (C)   Any member failing to meet the minimum 60 hours annual training will
not be in good standing regardless of his/her percentage of all non-EMS calls
for service answered by the department.
   (D)   Any member failing to meet the requirements shall be notified
quarterly by the Chief, in writing, for possible disciplinary action, up to and
including termination, by the Chief, his/her designee, or Village Board.
   (E)   Any member not in good standing will not be eligible for any possible
compensation from the village.
   (F)   Any member that has 15 or more years of services in good standing who
cannot meet these minimal requirements shall be given the option to retire.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-8) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86; Am. Ord. 2009-02, passed 1-
21-09; Am. Ord. 2015-45, passed 11-18-15; Am. Ord. 2023-06, passed 2-1-23)
§ 33.107 RETIREMENT.
   Any member who retires with 20 or more years of service in good-standing
shall automatically have all retirement and death benefits of the Madison
County and Illinois Firefighters Association paid in full in accordance with
payment plans set up by the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-9) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.108 INACTIVITY; GOOD-STANDING STATUS.
   (A)   In accordance with §
33.107, any member who has 20 or more years of active service who cannot meet
these minimum requirements will be placed without prejudice on “inactive
status.”
   (B)   Inactive status members may attend and maintain all privileges of
active members with the exception of the following:
      (1)   Vote at Departmental meetings; and
      (2)   Participate in emergency for firefighting duties.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-10) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.109 SUSPENSION OR DISCHARGE.
   (A)   Any firefighter shall be subject to suspension or discharge, for
cause, after a fair and impartial hearing before the Village Board, upon
written charges filed with the Board. The Board shall conduct the hearing
within 30 days of the filing thereof. In case an officer or firefighters of the
Fire Department is found guilty, the Board may discharge him or her or suspend
him or her for a definite term without pay.
   (B)   (1)   Additionally, the Chief of the Fire Department shall have the
power to suspend, without pay, a member of the Fire Department for a period of
not more than 30 days, but he or she shall notify the Village Board, in
writing, of the suspension.
      (2)   Any firefighter so suspended may appeal to the Village Board within
72 hours after the suspension, and upon the appeal, the Board may sustain the
action of the Chief, may reverse it or may suspend the firefighters for an
additional period of time certain, or may discharge him or her, depending on
the facts of the case.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-11) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
§ 33.110 GENERAL OPERATION.
   The following general provisions shall apply to the operation of the Fire
Department:
   (A)   The village shall furnish every firefighter of the Department with
uniforms and a badge or other identification designating his or her rank in the
Department.
   (B)   (1)   The village shall also furnish every active member with proper
protective clothing necessary for fire and emergency duties.
      (2)   These items to include, but are not limited to helmet, boots, coat,
pants, gloves and the like.
   (C)   (1)   Village fire apparatus shall have the right-of-way over all
other vehicular and pedestrian traffic only when responding to an alarm of fire
or other emergency call. It may, at that time, properly disregard traffic-
control signs and signals; provided, it takes due precautions by reducing
speed, by continuously operating its sirens and signal lights and using all
other safety precautions.
      (2)   When returning to the station after a fire response, it shall obey
all traffic signs and signals.
   (D)   Personal cars of firefighters of the Department may carry distinctive
lights as provided by state law, but they shall be used only in going to an
alarm of fire or emergency.
   (E)   No person shall drive any vehicle over hose laid at a fire where the
hose is in use, except by permission of the fire officer in charge there.
   (F)   No person shall park any vehicle or cause any obstruction within 15
feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station or within 15 feet of any fire
hydrant, nor shall the driver of any vehicle, except cars of firefighters,
follow within 500 feet of any fire apparatus responding to an alarm of fire,
nor park within 1,000 feet where the fire apparatus has stopped at a fire.
   (G)   No person shall interfere with a firefighter in the performance of his
or her duty, nor shall they refuse or neglect to furnish any firefighter any
help or information they may possess as to the cause or origin of any fire or
hinder any fire investigation in any manner.
   (H)   No person shall turn in, or cause to be turned in, any false alarm of
fire.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-12) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 33.111 DUTIES OF SPECTATORS.
   (A)   Every person above the age of 18 years of age, who shall be present at
a fire, shall be subject to the orders of the officer in command at the fire.
   (B)   Every person shall render all assistance in his or her power, and in
such manner as he or she may be directed, in the extinguishment of the fire and
in the removal of and protection of property.
   (C)   Any person refusing to obey such orders, shall, upon conviction, be
fined in any sum not exceeding $500, provided no person shall be bound to obey
any such officer unless the officer’s official character shall be made known to
the person.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-13) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 33.112 ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of all officers of the Fire Department and all
police officers of the village to see that the provisions of this subchapter
are enforced, and to arrest, on view, any person who shall be found violating
any of the provisions of the code, or who shall hinder, resist or refuse to
obey any officer in the discharge of his or her duty.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate any applicable provision of this code, or
interfere with or obstruct any firefighter or firefighters in the performance
of their duties hereunder or incidental thereto, shall, upon conviction of
violation hereof, be subject to a fine in an amount not to exceed $500.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-14) (Ord. 86-11, passed 5-7-86; Am. Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-
86)
Penalty, see § 10.99
§ 33.113 OUTSIDE SERVICE.
   (A)   There shall, henceforth, be assessed against all persons, businesses
and other entities which are not residents of the village, a charge for
services rendered by personnel and equipment used of the Fire Department.
   (B)   The charges provided for in this section shall not be assessed
against:
      (1)   Residents of the village;
      (2)   Residents of a county, municipality or fire protection district
which has a mutual aid or assistance agreement with the Fire Department; or
      (3)   Persons who request fire protection coverage for an unprotected
area and who pay to the Fire Department an amount equal to the Fire Protection
Tax pursuant to Section IV of “An Act Relating to Fire Protection in Certain
Areas,” approved September 18, 1975, as amended.
   (C)   (1)   The charges for services rendered by the Fire Department in
division (A) above shall be computed at the rate of $100 per hour per vehicle
and $25 per hour per firefighters, paramedics or other personnel, responding to
a call for assistance.
      (2)   An additional charge shall be levied to reimburse the Fire
Department for any extraordinary expenses of materials used in rendering the
services.
      (3)   No charge shall be made for services for which the total charge
would be less than $50.
   (D)   All receipts from charges assessed pursuant to this section shall be
deposited to and become a part of the General Fund of the village.
(`92 Code, § 30-4-15) (Ord. 86-27, passed 9-17-86)
AMBULANCE SERVICE
§ 33.125 PURPOSE OF SERVICE.
   The ambulance service shall be limited to emergency services for persons
who, in an emergency situation, require emergency medical aid or assistance
and/or transportation to obtain the aid or assistance.
(`92 Code, § 30-5-1) (Ord. 88-21, passed 12-21-88)
§ 33.126 DIRECTOR OF SERVICE.
   The Fire Chief or his or her designee is authorized to direct actions and to
take measures deemed necessary in responding to calls for emergency medical
transportation.
(`92 Code, § 30-5-2) (Ord. 88-21, passed 12-21-88)
§ 33.127 CHARGES TO BE PAID.
   Whenever a response is made upon request of a person, person’s parent,
guardian or agent or employer, there shall be paid by the person receiving the
benefit of service, person’s parent, family, guardian, agent or employer into
the Village Treasury, the sum as computed by the schedule set forth herein by §
33.129.
(`92 Code, § 30-5-3) (Ord. 88-21, passed 12-21-88)
§ 33.128 APPLICABLE CHARGES.

a victim in an emergency situation, there shall be paid by the person receiving
the benefit of the service, the person’s parent, family, guardian, agent or
employer into the Village Treasury the sum as computed by the schedule set
forth herein by § 133.129.
(`92 Code, § 30-5-4) (Ord. 88-21, passed 12-21-88)

§ 33.130 SERVICE AREA.
   (A)   The service area shall be limited to the corporate limits of the
village, except as may be expanded by a specific intergovernmental contract
with other governmental units to provide the service to their areas or by
request of a law enforcement officer in the event of emergency.
   (B)   In no event shall the designated service area or service provided
under this subchapter exceed a distance of ten miles from the Village Hall,
without prior written approval of the Fire Chief or his or her designated
agent.
(`92 Code, § 30-5-6) (Ord. 88-21, passed 12-21-88)

   (A)   The response of the village, upon request, for the transportation
service shall constitute an acceptance of the offer and approval of the fees
herein above stated.
   (B)   Any person directing a call for assistance shall be considered and
designated as the agent for the victim, victim’s parent, guardian, agent or
family or person receiving the benefit of ambulance service.

EMERGENCY MEDICAL TECHNICIANS
§ 33.145 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   There is hereby established the position of emergency medical technician,
advanced life support service paramedic level/firefighter, hereinafter “EMTP/
firefighter.” The Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Village Board,
shall fill the position with a fully qualified and certified EMTP/firefighter.
(`92 Code, § 30-6-1)
§ 33.146 COMPENSATION AND WORK WEEK.
   The hourly wage and/or benefits for the position shall be determined by the
Village Board. The individual selected will be a full time employee working 40
hours per week.
(`92 Code, § 30-6-2)
§ 33.147 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The duties of the position shall include, but shall not be limited to the
following:
   (A)   Respond to all ambulance calls, during duty hours, where an EMTP is
required; (This takes precedence over all other duties.)
   (B)   Be responsible for proper processing of Fire Department/ambulance
paperwork;
   (C)   Ensure proper Fire Department/ambulance equipment/vehicle maintenance
is scheduled and performed;
   (D)   Ensure Fire Department/ambulance vehicles are stocked with the proper
supplies and/or equipment;
   (E)   Conduct building/business fire inspections;
   (F)   Report directly and be responsible to the Fire Chief;
   (G)   Maintain his or her qualifications and certifications under the state
as an EMTP/firefighter; and
   (H)   Be a member in good standing in the Fire Department.
(`92 Code, § 30-6-3) (Ord. 95-21, passed 4-19-95)
PUBLIC SERVICE OFFICER
§ 33.160 POSITION ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   A new employee position of Public Service Officer (PSO) is hereby
established.
   (B)   The number of such positions and the number of scheduled working hours
shall be established by the corporate authorities from time to time.
   (C)   The person or persons appointed to such position shall be responsible
to the President and his or her designate(s).
   (D)   The Public Service Officer (PSO) shall be appointed annually by the
President with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees and shall serve
such annual appointment, unless otherwise removed for cause prior to that time.
(Ord. 2005-48, passed 9-21-05; Am. Ord. 2007-49, passed 9-19-07)
§ 33.161 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Public Service Officer shall:
   (A)   Be a high school graduate or GED equivalent;
   (B)   Have the ability to read, write, and speak the English language;
   (C)   Have the ability to compose letters and articulate thoughts and
interpretations;
   (D)   Have a working knowledge of computers and word processors;
   (E)   Possess a valid Illinois driver’s license and have the ability to
operate a motor vehicle without limitations or suspensions;
   (F)   Have the ability and willingness to understand and carry out oral and
written instructions;
   (G)   Consent to and successfully complete a criminal background check with
no felony convictions or misdemeanors involving theft, dishonesty, fraud,
deceptive practices, or crimes involving moral turpitude;
   (H)   Furnish the village with adequate recommendations, educational
credentials, and background documents;
   (I)   Have good physical and mental health and submit to and successfully
complete a physical examination and drug test and, during employment, submit to
drug testing if requested by superiors and/or hiring officials;
   (J)   Successfully complete any initial training program or other up-date
training programs as required by the President or his or her designee(s);
   (K)   Be at least 18 years old.
(Ord. 2005-48, passed 9-21-05; Am. Ord. 2007-49, passed 9-19-07)
§ 33.162 DUTIES.
   The duties of the Public Service Officer shall be:
   (A)   Parking and traffic control.
      (1)   Enforcement of any and all ordinances and statutes relative to
parking regulations within those areas of the village as assigned by the Police
Chief or his or her designee;
      (2)   Reporting to appropriate authorities the maintenance and repair
needs at any parking or other traffic control signs/devices or markings within
the assigned enforcement area;
      (3)   School and grade crossing guard duties as may be assigned by the
Chief of Police or his or her designee(s);
      (4)   Traffic direction and/or control whenever necessary due to the
limited availability of sworn personnel.
   (B)   Administration and enforcement of certain general offense provisions.
      (1)   Any and all ordinances and statutes pertaining to property
maintenance or management, including those set forth in the building code, the
subdivision code, or the zoning code, except as may be assigned by the
President in cooperation with other officials, including the Building and
Zoning Administrator;
      (2)   Ordinances and statutes pertaining to animals, including those
responsibilities formerly held by an animal control officer;
      (3)   Ordinances and statutes relative to safety, sanitation and health,
snow removal, and vegetation growth;
      (4)   Ordinances and statutes pertaining to littering.
   (C)   Enforcement of certain ordinances pertaining to business regulation
and taxation, provided that same is done with the approval of the President or
other appropriate officials.
      (1)   Inspections of business premises and operations to ensure
compliance with licensing requirements.
   (D)   Enforcement of certain provisions of the streets, utilities and public
services code, provided that same is done with the approval of the President
and, whenever necessary, in cooperation with other officials.
      (1)   Ordinances pertaining to trees overhanging streets and sidewalks;
      (2)   House numbering as same is required for placement on structures;
      (3)   Ordinances prohibiting littering within parks and otherwise
regulating use of parks by permit or designated area;
      (4)   Ordinances pertaining to required containers and placement and
removal of garbage and refuse.
   (E)   Enforcement of certain provisions of the planning and zoning code,
provided that same is done with the approval of the President and in
cooperation with other officials.
      (1)   Vision clearance on corner lots;
      (2)   Off-street parking requirements.
   (F)   General duties and any and all other duties as may be assigned by the
President.
      (1)   To effect the provisions of this section, any person or persons
appointed to the position hereby established are given full power and authority
to issue citations, tickets, or other documentation of violation of any
ordinance or statute within the corporate limits of the village and file same
with appropriate courts having jurisdiction;
      (2)   Perform residential vacation checks;
      (3)   Investigate derelict and abandoned vehicles and complaints related
to such, make notification to owner, and keep all records and reports of such;
      (4)   Report the need for emergency street repairs, traffic light
irregularities, streetlight outage, abandoned trash on streets and right-of-
ways, and dead animals on public streets and public property to the appropriate
village department; and
      (5)   Courier-deliver documents, messages, and the like as directed by
the President.
(Ord. 2005-48, passed 9-21-05; Am. Ord. 2007-49, passed 9-19-07)
§ 33.163 RESTRICTIONS ON THE OFFICE OF PUBLIC SERVICE OFFICER.
   (A)   The person or persons appointed to the position hereby established
shall not at any time carry a firearm or other deadly weapon or effect the
physical arrest of any individual unless otherwise directed by a peace officer.
   (B)   The person or persons appointed to the position hereby established
shall not at any time have the authority to perform any job or duty which is
specifically prohibited by state or federal law.
(Ord. 2005-48, passed 9-21-05)
